(Nena album)|?]] | next_year = 1984 | misc = {{Singles | name = Nena | type = studio | single1 = Nur geträumt | single1date = 1982 | single2 = [[99 Luftballons]] | single2date = 1983 | single3 = Leuchtturm | single3date = 1983 }} }} {{Album reviews |rev1=[[Allmusic]] |rev1score={{Rating|4|5}}{{cite web|last=Severa|first=Alan|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/nena-mw0000545839|title=Review of ''Nena'' by Nena|website=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=28 June 2013}} }} '''''Nena''''' is the first album by German [[pop rock]] band [[Nena (band)|Nena]] and the second studio album of its singer, [[Nena|Gabriele "Nena" Kerner]]. Released on 14 January 1983, it's been part of the music genre called [[Neue Deutsche Welle]] (meaning "New German Wave") movement in the [[German music]]. The album was a great success in [[West Germany]] and the second single "[[99 Luftballons]]" successfully reached {{nobr|No.{{space|hair}}1}} in the [[music charts]] worldwide including Australia, Austria, Canada, Ireland, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Sweden, Switzerland and the United Kingdom.{{cite web|url=http://www.austriancharts.at/showitem.asp?interpret=Nena&titel=99+Luftballons&cat=s|title=Chart positions for "99 Luftballons" by Nena|website=AustrianCharts.at|date=26 June 2013}} The single is largely considered a "[[one-hit wonder]]" by many, including [[VH1]].{{cite web|url=http://afrokayo.web.fc2.com/mdata_vh1_greatest_onehit_wonders.html |title=100 Greatest one-hit wonders |website=AfroKayo.web.fc2.com |accessdate=26 June 2013 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203021629/http://afrokayo.web.fc2.com/mdata_vh1_greatest_onehit_wonders.html |archivedate=3 February 2014 }} It was produced by [[:de:Manfred Praeker|Manfred Praeker]] and [[Reinhold Heil]] of the German band [[Spliff (band)|Spliff]].{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/nena-mw0000545839/credits|title=Credits for ''Nena'' by Nena|website=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=26 June 2013}} The album has been initially released as a [[vinyl LP]], [[Compact Cassette|cassette]] and [[compact disc|CD]]. The first single from the album, "Nur geträumt", was released a year earlier, in 1982. "99 Luftballons" was the second single, released in 1983. The third and final single was "Leuchtturm", released in 1983, a few months after "99 Luftballons". ==Prominent tracks== The three singles released from the ''Nena'' album have enjoyed particular prominence in [[Nena]]'s career. Although "[[99 Luftballons]]" is by far the most well known globally, the other two ("Nur geträumt" and "Leuchtturm") have for more than 30 years been ever-present features of the live concerts of firstly the band and then Nena in her subsequent solo career.{{cite web|title=Nena concerts and setlists|url=http://www.nena.de/gigografie|website=Nena.de|accessdate=23 November 2014}} ==="Nur geträumt"=== "Nur geträumt" was released in May 1982, eight months before the release of the album. Upon release, the single sold poorly. However, after Nena performed it on the TV programme ''[[Musikladen]]'' in August 1982, it catapulted the band to fame in Germany.{{cite web|title=Biography of Nena|url=https://www.prosieben.de/stars/star-datenbank/nena-gabriele-susanne-kerner|accessdate=23 September 2019}} Written by Nena and her boyfriend [[:de:Rolf Brendel|Rolf Brendel]], the band's drummer, it is about a couple longing to spend time together.{{cite web|title="Nur geträumt" lyrics and credits|url=http://www.nena.de/nur-geträumt|website=Nena.de|accessdate=23 November 2014}} It reached {{nobr|No.{{space|thin}}2}} in the German charts where it stayed for seven weeks from late October through early December 1982, being blocked from reaching {{nobr|No.{{space|hair}}1}} by {{nobr|[[F. R. David]]'s}} "Words".{{cite web|title=German charts – "Nur geträumt"|url=http://www.officialcharts.de/charts.asp?cat=s&country=de&year=1982&date=19821129&x=31&y=10|website=Officialcharts.de|publisher=[[GfK Entertainment Charts|GfK Entertainment]]|accessdate=23 November 2014}} [[File:Label LP Nena.JPG|thumb|left|LP label of the "Nena" album]]If the track was the one which launched Nena's career in Germany, where its release preceded "99 Luftballons", it had the opposite effect in the Anglophone world where an English version ("Just a Dream") failed as a follow-up, only scraping into the low reaches of the UK charts ({{nobr|No.{{space|thin}}70}}).{{cite web|title=Official UK charts - Nena|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/artist/_/nena/|website=Officialcharts.com|publisher=[[Official Charts Company]]|accessdate=23 November 2014}} In 2002, when Nena rekindled her solo career by releasing the triple platinum album ''[[Nena feat. Nena]]'' comprising re-worked versions of her 1980s greatest hits, "Nur geträumt" was among them. The album spawned three Top 10 hits in Germany but not the new version of "Nur geträumt", which only made {{nobr|No.{{space|thin}}79}}. Given the huge success of the album, by 2010 Nena had reverted to performing the original versions of most of the album's songs, including "Nur geträumt".See 2010 DVD "Made in Germany Live" ==="Leuchtturm"=== "Leuchtturm" is a love song, its lyrics, written by Nena herself, describing how she and her "Kapitän" (captain) set off alone in a "U-Boot" (submarine) to see the world from a "Leuchtturm" (Lighthouse). They enjoy themselves so much that by the time the submarine surfaces, the lighthouse is no longer in view. {{cite web|title="Leuchtturm" lyrics and credits|url=http://www.nena.de/leuchtturm|website=Nena.de|accessdate=23 November 2014}} Released as the follow-up to "99 Luftballons", it reached {{nobr|No.{{space|thin}}2}} in the German charts in 1983.{{cite web|title=Official German charts|url=http://www.officialcharts.de/suche.asp?search=nena&page=1&country=de&bereich=&chart=no&music=no&interpret=&titel=&release=&peak=&einstieg=&wochen=&kategorie=|website=Officialcharts.de|publisher=[[GfK Entertainment Charts|GfK Entertainment]]|accessdate=23 November 2014}} In 2001, a reggae-style version of "Leuchtturm" for Nena's solo album ''[[Chokmah (album)|Chokmah]]'' proved to be the precursor of the following year's ''Nena feat. Nena'' album, which was made up of updates of her 1980s greatest hits. Another version of "Leuchtturm" appeared on this 2002 album, this makeover both more fundamental and more enduring. The tempo of the song quickened and the lyrics were overhauled. With all mentions of captains and "U-Boots" removed, the song's message became a more generic affirmation of loyalty ("I'll go with you wherever you want... I won't ever leave you").{{cite web|title="Leuchtturm (2002)" lyrics and credits|url=http://www.nena.de/leuchtturm-2002|website=Nena.de|accessdate=23 November 2014}} The drift from the song's original meaning is best illustrated by the fact that the song's title "Leuchtturm" doesn't even appear in the new lyrics and the revised theme of unquestioning devotion led to it being adopted as a football chant by fans of Borussia Dortmund.{{cite web|title=Fan chants|url=http://nl.fanchants.de/football-songs/borussia-dortmund-chants/leuchtturm/|website=nl.fanchants.de|accessdate=23 November 2014}} The changes worked: "Leuchtturm (2002)", as it was officially titled, returned to the Top 10 of the German charts 19 years after its first appearance, this time peaking at {{nobr|No.{{space|thin}}7}}. Furthermore, despite the huge success of ''Nena feat. Nena'', "Leuchtturm" is the only re-work from the album which Nena hasn't discarded in favour of the original version, the 2002 version being the one she has continued to perform live ever since. In 2002 the single "Leuchtturm" was released with the additional title "Ich häng immer noch an dir" and with a remix by [[DJ Tomekk]].{{cite web|title=Single "Leuchtturm", 2002 on Nenas
